{{other ships|French ship Aréthuse|HMS Raven}} {|{{Infobox ship begin |infobox caption=''Aréthuse''}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=France |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|France|naval}} |Ship name=''Aréthuse'' |Ship namesake=[[Arethusa (mythology)|Arethusa]] |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=Louis and Antoine Crucy, Basse-Indre |Ship laid down=October 1797 |Ship launched=29 April 1798 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship captured=10 October 1799 |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate= |Ship status= |Ship honours= |Ship notes= }}
{{Infobox ship career |Hide header=title |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag={{shipboxflag|UK|naval}} |Ship name=''Raven'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship builder=Louis and Antoine Crucy, Basse-Indre |Ship laid down= |Ship launched= |Ship acquired=10 October 1799 |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship captured= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship fate=Wrecked on 6 July 1804 |Ship status= |Ship honours= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption=<ref name=Winfield/><ref name=WR>Winfield and Roberts (2015), p. 208.</ref> |Ship type=[[Corvette]] |Ship tons burthen= 389 {{small|{{frac|82|94}}}} ([[Builder's Old Measurement|bm]]), 250 (French; "of load") |Ship displacement=464 tons |Ship length={{convert|31.18|m|ft|abbr=on}} (overall); {{convert|27.93|m|ft|abbr=on}} (keel) |Ship beam={{convert|8.93|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship hold depth={{convert|4.38|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|3.8|m|ft|abbr=on}} |Ship sailplan= [[Full-rigged ship]] |Ship complement=*'''French service''': 136 *'''British service''': 96 |Ship armament=*'''French service''': 18 × 8-pounder long guns *'''British service''': 16 × 18-pounder [[carronade]]s + 2 × 6-pounder [[Chase gun|bow guns]] }} |} '''''Aréthuse''''', launched in April 1798, was the name-ship of the eponymous [[Aréthuse class corvette|''Aréthuse''-class corvette]]s of the [[French Navy]]. {{HMS|Excellent|1787|2}} captured her in 1799. The [[Royal Navy]] took her into service under the name '''HMS ''Raven'''''. She was wrecked in 1804.
==French service== Jean-François Gauthier designed her and she was the only vessel of her class. She carried only 18 cannon, though she was designed for 20.
''Aréthuse'' served between France and the Caribbean. On 9 October 1799 she was sailing towards {{HMS|Impregnable|1786|2}} and her convoy when the 74-gun ''Excellent'', which was to windward of ''Impregnable'', spotted her. ''Excellent'' chased ''Aréthuse'', catching her during the night. Captain Robert Stopford of ''Excellent'' described ''Aréthuse'' as having eighteen 9-pounder guns and a crew of 153 men, all under the command of a ''lieutenant de vaisseau''. She was sailing from Lorient to Cayenne with dispatches that she succeeded in destroying before she [[striking the colours|struck]].<ref>{{London Gazette|startpage=1066|issue=15195|date=15 October 1799}}</ref> ''Excellent'' shared the capture with ''Impregnable''.<ref>{{London Gazette|startpage=129|issue=15229|date=8 February 1800}}</ref>
==British service== ''Aréthuse'' arrived in Plymouth on 26 November 1799. Four hundred French prisoners from ''Aréthuse'' and [[Bordelais (1798 ship)|''Bourdelaise'']] had landed there two days earlier.<ref>''Naval Chronicle'', Vol. 2, p.542.</ref> ([[French frigate Révolutionnaire (1794)|''Revolutionnaire'']] had captured ''Bordelais'' on 11 October.) ''Aréthuse'' was fitted for service with the Royal Navy between September and December 1800.<ref name=Winfield/> She was commissioned in September 1800 under Commander James Sanders for the Channel.<ref name=Winfield>Winfield (2008), p.286.</ref> She was recommissioned in June 1802 under Commander [[s:A Naval Biographical Dictionary/Swaine, Spelman|Spelman Swaine]] and in August sailed for the Mediterranean.<ref name=Winfield/>
==Fate== On 4 January 1804 ''Raven'' sailed from Malta as escort to the merchant ship ''Dolphin'', bound for Naples.<ref name=Hepper>Hepper (1994), p.104.</ref> She was following a course along the south coast of Sicily that would take her between the islands of [[Favignana]] and Marettimo. In the evening of the next day [[master's mate]] Robert Incledon had the watch and saw a light shape in the moonless night.<ref name=Hepper/> He thought it was a sail but it turned out to be a tower on the cliffs near [[Mazara del Vallo|Mazari]], on the south west coast of Sicily. At 11pm she ran aground.<ref name=Hepper/> Despite efforts to lighten and free her, efforts that extended into the afternoon of 6 January, the pumps were unable to clear the water that was coming in and she had to be abandoned. ''Dolphin'' rescued her crew.<ref name=Hepper/> The court martial on 10 February 1805 admonished the master for having steered too near the land.<ref>Gossett (1986), p.41.</ref>
==See also== *[[List of ships captured in the 19th century]] *[[Glossary of nautical terms]]

(Seaforth Publishing). ISBN 9781848322042
